name: Bionics4Education Bionic Fish

overview.goal: You learn how to handle the Bionic Fish.
overview.previous: You should know how to use the Open Roberta Connector.
overview.description: In this tutorial you learn how to handle the Bionic Fish. You will control servo motors and let the fish swim. For this you have to build the fish according to this tutorial and have installed the Open Roberta Connector. Follow these instructions. We have also already added the motor in the configuration, you normally have to do this yourself, how to do this is explained here.

step.program: <block_set xmlns="http://de.fhg.iais.roberta.blockly" robottype="ev3" xmlversion="" description="" tags=""><instance x="319" y="-103"><block type="robControls_start_ardu" id="5;|8}vOKeFL`!t)^NJvU" intask="true" deletable="false"><mutation declare="false"></mutation><field name="DEBUG"></field></block><block type="robControls_loopForever_ardu" id="}E{u4u[v[6?CE0s~pPmU" intask="true" deletable="false" movable="false"></block></instance></block_set>
step.instruction:
As you can see, a program for the Bionics4Education robots already starts with a loop.

Within this starting block you can program your Bionics4Education robot.

In the next step you add the first programming block.

This is already set up in the configuration at port 1 (far left on the board), you can find the corresponding programming block the left in the category »Action«.

  •     Drag the block into the program.
step.toolbox:
<toolbox_set id="toolbox" style="display: none">
  <category name="TOOLBOX_ACTION" svg="true">
    
    <block type="robActions_motor_on_for_ardu">
      <value name="POWER">
        <block type="math_number" id="Dy#ytr1sQ2WFyWrdDQ_!" intask="true">
          <field name="NUM">90</field>
        </block>
      </value>
    </block>
    
  </category>
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
</toolbox_set>

tip: Dein Servomotor kann sich nur im Wertebereich 0 - 180° bewegen, die Standardposition 90° liegt daher in der Mitte.

step.instruction:
You can change the input value of the servo motor block by clicking into the blue number block. If the position is changed to 60°, the motor will move to this position accordingly.

Give it a try!

  •     Change the value of the servo motor to 60°.
  •     Connect to the robot using the connectors.
  •     Transfer the program with the »Start«      button.

The motor should move to the specified 60°.

Now what? Nothing happens anymore! Go on to the next step.
step.program: <block_set xmlns="http://de.fhg.iais.roberta.blockly" robottype="festobionic" xmlversion="" description="" tags=""><instance x="319" y="-103"><block type="robControls_start_ardu" id="5;|8}vOKeFL`!t)^NJvU" intask="true" deletable="false"><mutation declare="false"></mutation><field name="DEBUG"></field></block><block type="robControls_loopForever_ardu" id="}E{u4u[v[6?CE0s~pPmU" intask="true" deletable="false" movable="false"><statement name="DO"><block type="robActions_motor_on_for_ardu" id="uvDNSYuox`pRXN:URX{w" intask="true"><field name="MOTORPORT">S</field><value name="POWER"><block type="math_number" id="Dy#ytr1sQ2WFyWrdDQ_!" intask="true"><field name="NUM">60</field></block></value></block></statement></block></instance></block_set>

step.header: This is where movement comes in!

</toolbox_set>
step.instruction:
Currently the action is simply repeated infinitely, but since the motor is already set to 60°, nothing happens.

For this we need another programming block that addresses the servo motor, this time with a different value.

  •     Add another block.
  •     Change the value of the second programming blocks to 120°.
  •     Transfer the program to your robot.

What? Still nothing happens! Go on to the next step!
step.solution:

step.program: <block_set xmlns="http://de.fhg.iais.roberta.blockly" robottype="festobionic" xmlversion="" description="" tags=""><instance x="319" y="-103"><block type="robControls_start_ardu" id="5;|8}vOKeFL`!t)^NJvU" intask="true" deletable="false"><mutation declare="false"></mutation><field name="DEBUG"></field></block><block type="robControls_loopForever_ardu" id="}E{u4u[v[6?CE0s~pPmU" intask="true" deletable="false" movable="false"><statement name="DO"><block type="robActions_motor_on_for_ardu" id="uvDNSYuox`pRXN:URX{w" intask="true"><field name="MOTORPORT">S</field><value name="POWER"><block type="math_number" id="Dy#ytr1sQ2WFyWrdDQ_!" intask="true"><field name="NUM">60</field></block></value></block><block type="robControls_wait_time" id="({m84})p;9lZVGoU()rT" intask="true"><value name="WAIT"><block type="math_number" id="1z?NfShG~]`M:q1y(hG5" intask="true"><field name="NUM">500</field></block></value></block><block type="robActions_motor_on_for_ardu" id="b3N7yZ{+kPsV-+Jmi[u{" intask="true"><field name="MOTORPORT">S</field><value name="POWER"><block type="math_number" id="gnNrhC}..!*uZmMT/Mga" intask="true"><field name="NUM">120</field></block></value></block><block type="robControls_wait_time" id=":1nP2o`k`NK80o8Q2Fxq" intask="true"><value name="WAIT"><block type="math_number" id="ye-!D8}dDRm)=(cMv:t-" intask="true"><field name="NUM">500</field></block></value></block></statement></block></instance></block_set>
step.toolbox:
<toolbox_set id="toolbox" style="display: none">
  <category name="TOOLBOX_ACTION" svg="true">
    
    <block type="robActions_motor_on_for_ardu">
      <value name="POWER">
        <block type="math_number" id="Dy#ytr1sQ2WFyWrdDQ_!" intask="true">
          <field name="NUM">90</field>
        </block>
      </value>
    </block>
    
  </category>
  
  <category name="TOOLBOX_CONTROL" svg="true">
    
    
    
  <block type="robControls_wait_time">
        <value name="WAIT">
          <block type="math_number">
            <field name="NUM">500</field>
          </block>
        </value>
      </block></category>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</toolbox_set>
step.instruction:
Even small microcontrollers like your Bionics4Education run incredibly fast, in the current program the motor just can't keep up with the fast change of positions.

To give the motor a bit of time to take the desired position we need the block from the »Control« category. This block makes your fish wait a certain number of milliseconds (1 s has 1000 ms).

  •     Use two blocks to give the robot time to reach the position.
  •     Transfer the program and see how your fish swims!
step.solution:

step.toolbox:
<toolbox_set id="toolbox" style="display: none">
  <category name="TOOLBOX_ACTION" svg="true">
    
    <block type="robActions_motor_on_for_ardu">
      <value name="POWER">
        <block type="math_number" id="Dy#ytr1sQ2WFyWrdDQ_!" intask="true">
          <field name="NUM">90</field>
        </block>
      </value>
    </block>
    
  </category>
  
  <category name="TOOLBOX_CONTROL" svg="true">
    
    
    
  <block type="robControls_wait_time">
        <value name="WAIT">
          <block type="math_number">
            <field name="NUM">500</field>
          </block>
        </value>
      </block></category>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</toolbox_set>

step.instruction:
Try to make the fish swim faster, so that it still manages to do the full fin swing.

  •     Change the waiting times to make the fish swim faster.
  •     Transfer the program and test different speeds!
tip:
The less you wait, the faster the fish will move!

But be careful, the engines need some time to reach the positions.

end: You did it! Now you can let your fish swim at different speeds!
